paragraphs.name: 4aa3
paragraphs.text: Learning transfer is taking what we learn in one context and applying it to another. It can be taking a kernel of what we learn in school or in a book and applying it to the “real world.” It can also be taking what we learn in one industry and applying it to another.

Keith Holyoak, a UCLA professor of psychology and one of the world’s leading thinkers on analogical reasoning, recommends people ask themselves the following two questions in order to hone their skills: “What does this remind me of?” and “Why does it remind me of it?”
paragraphs.name: 54d2

paragraphs.text: Based on my review of Musk’s life and the academic literature related to learning and expertise, I’m convinced that we should ALL learn across multiple fields in order to increase our odds of breakthrough success.
paragraphs.name: 4bd9

paragraphs.text: Keith Holyoak, a UCLA professor of psychology and one of the world’s leading thinkers on analogical reasoning, recommends people ask themselves the following two questions in order to hone their skills: “What does this remind me of?” and “Why does it remind me of it?”
paragraphs.name: 54d2

paragraphs.text: In a previous article, I call people like Elon Musk “expert-generalists” (a term coined by Orit Gadiesh, chairman of Bain & Company). Expert-generalists study widely in many different fields, understand deeper principles that connect those fields, and then apply the principles to their core specialty.
paragraphs.name: cca8

paragraphs.text: I agree that Musk is proof that being a polymath (or an “expert-generalist”) is a viable path. However, I believe you would be making the same mistake we have always made. Believing that one shoe size fits all. All we can truly garner from this is that generality can work equally as great as being specific.
